composition.title: What is Composition?
composition.description: In photography, composition refers to the way visual elements are arranged within the frame. Unlike traditional visual arts, photography relies heavily on the recognizability of subjects, which can become symbols in their own right. A good composition directs the viewer's eye and helps communicate meaning or emotion effectively.

Rule of Thirds.description: This classic technique divides the frame into nine equal sections using two vertical and two horizontal lines. Placing key subjects along these lines or their intersections creates a balanced, visually pleasing photo.
Rule of Thirds.details: Used in everything from portraits to landscapes, the rule of thirds helps naturally guide the viewer’s attention. Compositions can also incorporate triangular arrangements, which add harmony and structure.

Leading Lines.description: Leading lines are elements within the photo that draw the viewer’s eye to the main subject or through the scene.
Leading Lines.details: These lines can be roads, fences, rivers, or even shadows. Diagonal lines, in particular, add a dynamic, forward-moving energy. They help create a sense of motion or guide the narrative of the photo.

Symmetry and Patterns.description: Symmetry and repetition offer a sense of harmony, order, and visual appeal.
Symmetry and Patterns.details: Horizontal, vertical, or radial symmetry creates balance, while repeating shapes or forms create rhythm and structure. These elements often result in clean, impactful photographs.

Framing.description: Framing uses elements in the scene to create a visual frame around the subject, drawing attention and adding depth.
Framing.details: Windows, arches, tree branches, or even light and shadows can serve as frames, guiding the viewer’s focus and enhancing the image’s story.

Negative Space.description: Negative space refers to the empty or unoccupied areas around the subject.
Negative Space.details: This space can help isolate the subject, create mood, or offer balance. It's especially effective in minimalist or nature photography, where space enhances the visual message.

Layering Elements.description: Layering introduces depth and dimension by including foreground, middle ground, and background.
Layering Elements.details: It adds realism and storytelling power. Photographers must be aware of every plane in the scene and use them intentionally to guide the eye and build complexity.

Balance.description: Balance involves arranging elements so that no part of the image feels heavier or out of proportion.
Balance.details: This can be achieved through symmetry or asymmetry, using elements of similar or contrasting size, color, and texture to create harmony. Visual balance gives structure and meaning to the composition.

Perspectives and Viewpoints.description: Changing the angle or point of view offers new ways to see and understand the subject.
Perspectives and Viewpoints.details: A high-angle (bird’s-eye) view can create distance or overview, while a low-angle (worm’s-eye) view can make the subject feel powerful or heroic. A direct, eye-level view builds connection. These choices influence how the audience emotionally relates to the image.

Open vs Closed Composition.challenge: Understanding how to place subjects within the frame to convey intention.
Open vs Closed Composition.solution: Open compositions suggest movement and extend beyond the frame; closed compositions contain all visual action within the borders. Choose based on your message and visual flow.

Static vs Dynamic Composition.challenge: Making a composition feel either calm or full of motion.
Static vs Dynamic Composition.solution: Horizontal and vertical lines usually feel static and stable; diagonal lines feel energetic and suggest movement. Use diagonal or spiral layouts for action and energy.

Compositional Schemes.challenge: Choosing a visual layout for different types of subjects.
Compositional Schemes.solution: Try pyramid (stable or inverted), circular (focus inward), elliptical (for movement), diagonal (for dynamism), or horizontal/vertical layers (for structure or hierarchy).

Visual Weight and Equilibrium.challenge: Balancing elements in the image so it doesn’t feel lopsided.
Visual Weight and Equilibrium.solution: Position visual elements with equal weight (through similarity or contrast) across the frame. This creates harmony between left/right and top/bottom areas.

Chromatic.title: The Basics of Chromatics
Chromatic.description: Chromatics is the study of color: its origins, combinations, contrasts, and effects. In photography, understanding color helps shape the mood, depth, and emotion of an image.

Primary and Secondary Colors.description: Primary colors are the basic building blocks of all other colors.
Primary and Secondary Colors.details: Red, yellow, and blue are primary colors. Mixing two primaries gives you secondary colors: red + yellow = orange, red + blue = violet, yellow + blue = green.

Complementary Colors.description: Complementary colors are pairs that sit opposite each other on the color wheel.
Complementary Colors.details: When combined, they produce white light. Examples include red-green, blue-orange, yellow-violet. These combinations create high contrast and vibrant harmony.

Warm and Cool Colors.description: Colors are also divided by temperature, affecting how they feel emotionally.
Warm and Cool Colors.details: Warm colors (red, orange, yellow) feel energetic or cozy. Cool colors (blue, green, violet) feel calm or distant. Balancing both can create mood and contrast.

Chromatic Contrasts.description: Different types of color contrast can change how viewers perceive an image.

concepts.Pure Color Contrast: Using multiple bold, pure colors creates strong visual energy. Black and white can boost this effect.
concepts.Warm vs Cool Contrast: Pairing warm and cool tones emphasizes temperature and spatial depth.
concepts.Complementary Contrast: Putting opposites (like red and green) side by side makes both colors pop.
concepts.Quality Contrast: Mixing bright, saturated colors with dull or muted ones creates tension and focus.
concepts.Quantity Contrast: Using more of one color and a little of another makes the smaller amount stand out more.
concepts.Simultaneous Contrast: The human eye naturally enhances the presence of a color’s opposite. A neutral gray next to green may appear reddish.
concepts.Light vs Dark (Chiaroscuro): Combining bright and dark versions of colors (lightened with white or darkened with black) enhances drama and form.

color_balance.solution: Use custom white balance settings or presets based on the lighting environment (e.g., daylight, tungsten, fluorescent). Shoot in RAW format to adjust white balance accurately during post-processing or use gray cards and color checker tools for more precise calibration.

color_casts.challenge: Unwanted color tints due to mixed or uneven lighting
color_casts.solution: Avoid mixed lighting (e.g., combining natural light and artificial light) that can cause unwanted color tints. Use lens filters or gels to balance light sources. Correct tints using color correction tools in photo editing software.

oversaturation_or_flat_colors.challenge: Colors that appear either too intense or washed out
oversaturation_or_flat_colors.solution: Adjust saturation and vibrance carefully in post-processing to maintain natural tones. Use the correct picture style or profile settings in-camera. Balance exposure and lighting to prevent colors from washing out or becoming overly intense.

distracting_color_combinations.challenge: Clashing colors between subject, clothing, and background
distracting_color_combinations.solution: Learn and apply basic color theory (e.g., complementary, analogous colors) for harmony. Choose backgrounds and wardrobe that do not clash with the subject. Use selective color adjustments in editing to unify or tone down problematic areas.

low_chromatic_contrast.challenge: Subject blends into the background due to similar colors
low_chromatic_contrast.solution: Increase the difference between subject and background colors to make the subject stand out. Use lighting techniques (like backlighting or side-lighting) to separate elements. Convert to black and white if color separation fails and focus on tonal contrast instead.
